title.narrative: Providing emergency RH services, GBV mitigation and response services, and RRM for the most vulnerable people from Marib and Al Jawf.

description.narrative: Recent trend analyses of gender-based violence indicate increased numbers of women and girls (widows, orphans) engaging in negative coping mechanisms (especially child marriage) and an increase in reported cases of sexual violence, physical and psychological assault. GBV partners have seen an increased demand for GBV services by 37%. Furthermore, the UNFPA-led Rapid Response Mechanism estimates that 23% of those newly displaced are female-headed households. With the current conflict, the health system in Yemen has almost collapsed, with only half of the facilities functional. Majority of those still functional face severe shortages of medicines, equipment and staff. Most of the health staff have not been paid government salaries for the last five years. This has naturally led to a deterioration in all the key reproductive health indicators. The CERF funding will lead to three key outputs. First, it will allow 16 health facilities to provide emergency obstetric and neonatal care services. This will directly lead to the continuation of critical life-saving RH services in health facilities in districts with the highest severity indices in Marib and Al Jawf. CERF will also support seven safe spaces to provide survivor-centered multi-sectoral services (case management, psychosocial, medical, legal, livelihood) and a safe shelter for women and girls, which is a key intervention which can be life-saving. Both safe spaces and shelters provide the multi-sectorial services to the most vulnerable women and girls. However, the safe shelters also provide accommodation for the additionally vulnerable and/or face life-threatening situations or intense forms of GBV, and have no other resort. This project will also support the RRM in assistaing those newly displaced from Marib and Al Jawf with immediate life-saving assistance. The Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) provides immediate in-kind assistance (Immediate Response Rations from WFP, basic hygiene kits from UNICEF and dignity kits from UNFPA) to newly displaced persons and those impacted by natural disasters within 72 hours of receiving the displacement alert.
